awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Security of Smart Things: From Small Devices to Large Infrastructures
awd_abstract_narration:
This funding establishes a new Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at the Florida International University. Undergraduate students from across the nation will participate in summer research focused on the security of smart devices, particularly wearable devices.  The research projects will introduce practical innovations and testbeds for maintaining the privacy and security of smart devices such as wearable technologies, sensors, and mobile devices as well as smart infrastructures involving smart buildings, smart grids, and smart lighting and communication infrastructures.  The students should acquire skills that will lead to rewarding professional careers in areas that are vital for preserving our national security.

The students will learn how to design, implement, and assess research projects in areas that are needed to ensure safety and privacy of all citizens. The site will focus on recruiting under-represented minorities, particularly drawing on the surrounding universities with large Hispanic populations. The students will use of state-of-the art facilities and devices run by faculty members with significant expertise in the security of smart things.  The goals of the project include providing a quality research experience for undergraduates, increasing participation of female and under-represented minorities in computing fields, and preparing students to pursue graduate studies in cyber security fields, and building a community of security of smart things researchers.  This site is co-funded by the CISE Secure and Trustworthy Cyberspace (SaTC) Program.

por.por_cntn:
The REU Site at Florida International University in the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering focused on security and privacy aspects of smart things which coould be deployed in our daily lives and within our critical infrastructures. The site trained 36 students in 3 years and involved them in various practical projects under the supervision of 8 faculty mentors. The following summarizes the coutcomes and findings: 

- One of the goals of the REU Site was to provide opportunities to minority students. To this end, a diverse body of students (i.e., 47% minority and 25% female) was hired.  In addition, about 36% of these students came from non-traditional schools which did not have PhD programs.

- The students contributed to critical projects that relate to cybersecurity of smart things. 13 of the students were able to publish their work in peer-reviewed venues while some of them are still working on their papers. In addition, one of the students published in a top-ranked journal while another was able to file a joint patent for a new attack to smart devices using the Zigbee communication protocol. These achievements are exceptional for students at the undergradaute level. 

- The REU program also made a major impact on the career paths of these participating students. So far among graduates, 4 of them joined the graduate schools in various universities while many of them got prestigious jobs in STEM related companies and government institutions. 

- The REU program featured various speakers from academia and industry on topics that relate to professional development. This contributed to the skills of the participating students in terms of paper writing, technical presentations, poster design, and literature research. 

- There were various technical innovations that came out from this program. Some selected brief results are as follows:

   * One of the projects led to a new zero-day attack for a wireless communication standard, Zigbee and proposed a countermeasure.

   * A new privacy-preserving indoor localization app is designed and developed using the state of the art homomorphic encryption techniques. 

  * A reliable wireless mesh protocol was adapted to be used for distributed control among microgrids. 

  * A novel covert channel was developed using the Android Status bar notifications for smart watches. 

  * Machine learning techniques were used to determine the actual charging status of the electric car batteries.
